Comment: On tour in 1964, I experimented with 5 N-B5. If then 5... Q-B2 6 B-Q3 BxB 7 NxB P-K3, White has more space, and the Knight discourages ...P-QB4 or ...P-K4.

The start of a faulty concept. 13.. B-Q3 14 N-K4 B-B5 ch 15 K-N1 N-K4! 16 NxN BxN equalizes.
He still has time to back out with 14... Q-B2.

A clear refutation. The Queen's retreat is cut off and the weakness on Black's KB2 etched sharply.
What else?

Probably what Steinmeyer overlooked when he went into this whole mess. On 17...QxN 18 RxN Q-K6 (else 19 R-B3 winning the Q) 19 R-K2 Q-B5 20 NxKBP wins at least the exchange. So Black resigns. [Fischer, on the tournament as a whole] Motivated by my lopsided result (11-0), Dr. Hans Kmoch congratulated the runner-up, Evans, on "winning" the tournament... and then he congratulated me on "winning the exhibition."
